Purita is 50 years old and married with 10 children. 

Purita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a 29,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional items like sugar, milk, groceries, etc. to sell. 

Purita has borrowed and repaid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari sari store for five years and also earns an income from selling rice and farming sugarcane. 

Purita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Ruby owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling used  clothing or ukay-ukay products in the local community. Ruby has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ruby joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruby is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock of used clothing. This will be the first loan to be taken out by Ruby from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of used clothing

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is married with six children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Erlinda is 63 years old. She has a restaurant business in the Philippines. 

Erlinda requested a PHP 15,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Erlinda has been in this business for six years. In the future, Erlinda would like to save money to expand her business further.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new cows to replace her old cows.

loans.name: Norman

texts.en:
Norman is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. He is 30 years old, married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Norman owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & detergents in the local community. Norman has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Norman joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norman is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Norman from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & beverages

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married woman with 5 children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past five years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling household items like maize flour, wheat flour, sugar and rice. She faces a major challenge of theft because of lack of security in her area. Pauline dreams of establishing a poultry farm in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to install water pipes for the purpose of plumbing in her house. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to install water pipes for plumbing in her house

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is a hardworking, married man. He lives with his three children in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is solely responsible financially for looking after his family. His dream is to educate his children and build a permanent house. He has been rearing pigs for four years and is amazed with the rate of multiplication. He has a challenge of high cost of feeds and his desire is to own at least 50 pigs. Emmanuel needs the loan to buy pigs for rearing.

loans.use: To buy pigs for rearing.

loans.name: Barsbold

texts.en: Mr.Barsbold, 33, lives with his mother and a younger brother in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His mother is a pensioner and his younger brother is unemployed at the moment. Barsbold is an engineer, and has worked for a construction company in the past. He now rents a restaurant and also runs it. The restaurant is made as a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. It looks like a huge dome and has the capacity to serve 30 people at one time. It attracts customers, especially tourists, in the summer season. He is very enthusiastic about his new business and dreams of building his own restaurant someday. His customers are now increasing due to the forthcoming spring and summer seasons. He is asking a loan for replacing some kitchen appliances and for buying more products to increase his serving capacity.

loans.use: to replace some kitchen appliances for his restaurant and to buy more products to increase his serving capacity.

loans.name: Eleseo

texts.en:
Eleseo is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. He is 40 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Eleseo owns & operates a business venture in the food sector buying & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling breads, biscuits & pastries in the local community. Eleseo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Eleseo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleseo is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, sugar & eggs. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Eleseo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, sugar & eggs

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is 34 years old and married. She has two children, aged 8 and 1.

Lilibeth runs an eatery. She cooks the viands herself. Lilibeth has had her business for 8 years. She also raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase pig feeds and raw ingredients for cooking viands. Lilibeth works hard to improve her businesses. She hopes to save for her children's future.

loans.use: to purchase pig feeds and raw ingredients for cooking viands

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is 52 years old and married with eight children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy item to sell like milk, shampoo, etc. in her sari-sari store.

Merlinda has borrowed and repaid 19 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari (variety) store for 25 years and also earns an income from buying and selling fruits and vegetables.

Merlinda aspires to save enough money for business expansion and home renovation.

loans.use: To buy items to sell in her sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is married and has five children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

Beatrice has been operating a clothes-selling business for the past three years, selling from home and door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation for her business.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to do plumbing in her house, purchase water meter, pipes and iron sheets. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To do plumbing in her house, purchase water meter, pipes and iron sheets.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana sells a variety of vegetables and spices in their community. She has been in this business for 15 long years, earning PHP  5,000 net income monthly. In the future, Susana would like to see her business grow. She wants to sell not just vegetables and spices but various products such as meat and food snacks. 

Susana is married with four school-aged children. She is now 40 years and believes that "life begins at 40".  She chooses to venture in a food selling business to support her family's daily needs. 

Susana is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy various vegetables like cabbage, squash, eggplant, and spices such as onions, garlic and ginger.

loans.use: to buy various vegetables like cabbage, squash, eggplant, and spices such as onions, garlic and ginger.

loans.name: Sabtoria

texts.en:
Sabtoria is married and works hard to support 4 children. She lives in the Philippines. Sabtoria buys and sells bananas and vegetables. She has been in this business for fifteen years.

Sabtoria has requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of bananas and vegetables to sell. In the future, she would like to expand her business and buy a delivery truck.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of bananas and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is married and works hard to support her family in the Philippines. For twelve years she has bought and sold scrap materials.

Marilou has requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more scrap materials such as empty bottles, iron, plastic, etc. to sell. In the future, Marilou would like to expand her business and repair and renovate her family’s home.

loans.use: to purchase more scrap materials to sell.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is 35 years old, married and has two children who are in school. She raises pigs in the Philippines and has been doing so for ten years now.

Nora has requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has taken out seven loans in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Nora would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Khalid

texts.en:
Khalid, 39 years old, is married to Naimah, 31, and has five children. They have been living in a rented house in A. Zarqa for five years now.
Khalid owns a small restaurant that sells hummus, falafel and sandwiches in a very active area where most of the people come to buy breakfast from him. He has been working in this field for four years. Now Khalid wants to expand and improve the service he provides at his restaurant by adding another refrigerator for drinks. That’s why he applied for this loan.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for drinks for his restaurant

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kheng is a rice farmer in the Baray district of Kompong Tom province. To earn additional income, Mrs. Kheng sells fresh fish at market, earning about $2 each day. Her husband assists her in this business. They have six children, one of whom is employed.

Mrs. Kheng is requesting a loan to use toward the planting of rice crops during the rainy season.

loans.use: to plant rice crops during the rainy season

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma, age 38, is a vegetable farmer in the Philippines. She has been farming vegetables for five years now, and has borrowed 16 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Wilma is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other necessary farm supplies.

She and her husband have five children, four of whom are enrolled in school. Her hope for the future is to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other necessary farm supplies

loans.name: Alfreda

texts.en:
Alfreda is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 57 years old. Alfreda is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Alfreda owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from buying and retailing rice (per kilogram) in the local community. Alfreda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Alfreda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alfreda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell. This loan will be Alfreda's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional generated revenue to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita, age 60, works hard to provide for her family. She has owned and operated a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines for the past 21 years and also earns additional income from a coffee shop business. She has borrowed and repaid 17 loans from NWTF and is currently requesting a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more merchandise to offer for sale.
 
Teresita is married and has one child. In the future, she aspires to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to offer for sale

loans.name: Kulsun's Group

texts.en:
Kulsun is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married to beekeeper. She has raised three daughters and a son with her husband. Her son serves in the army, her youngest daughter graduates school this year, and her other two daughters are married and live with their families. Kulsun works as a teacher in the Education Centre, where she teaches children how to sew clothes. In order to contribute additional money to her family's budget she sells 9-10 liters of milk every day (for 9 soms per liter). Through this business, she earns 2000 soms.  With the money gained from milk sales Kulsun purchases livestock to breed. She is requesting this loan to purchase a bull-calf to breed. In the future, Kulsun wants to see her son get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious, and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a bull-calf.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Rosalina is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Rosalina owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, junk food, biscuits, shampoo, soap, and detergents in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods, and biscuits to sell. This loan will be Rosalina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk food, and biscuits to sell in her retail store.

loans.name: Guali

texts.en:
As a married parent of 6 children, Guali works hard to support his family.

He buys and sells bananas and spices in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a Sari Sari Store business. Guali is borrowing PHP 24500 through NWTF to purchase bananas and spices to sell.

Guali has been sustaining his business activities through his past 7 loans from NWTF. He hopes that his hard work will help him attain his dream to save enough money so he could afford to send his children to college.

loans.use: To purchase bananas and spices to sell

loans.name: Sukhbaatar

texts.en:
Sukhbaatar is 58 years old and lives with his wife, son and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in a small house in the outer ger districts of the city. His son works at a local trade center and his daughter attends public school. Sukhbaatar is a professional driver, having worked at a local auto company from 1975 to 1997.

Sukhbaatar has been supporting his family by operating a taxi business for the past thirteen years. In 1998, he started his business using an old Russian car called a Moskvich. During the past thirteen years, he has been able to gradually improve his living conditions and has gained a lot of experience. He is planning to sell his old car and purchase another secondhand car, due to safety regulations for transportation. He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase the car. His goal is to improve his daughter’s education by paying her education costs.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand car.

loans.name: Laudencia

texts.en:
Laudenia, age 48, is a fish vendor in the Philippines. She has been in this business for four years and is a very hard-working entrepreneur. She and her husband have three children, all enrolled in school.

Laudenia has requested a PHP 17,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more fish to offer for sale.

In the future, Laudenia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish to offer for sale

loans.name: Manolita

texts.en:
Manolita is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 66 years old, married and has 6 adult-aged children. Manolita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages,  shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Manolita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Manolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manolita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and beverages. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Manolita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and beverages.

loans.name: Ke

texts.en:
Mrs. Ke is a secondhand clothing vendor. She sells clothing for both men and women in and around her village. She and her husband have three children, all of whom are enrolled in school. The family lives in the Baray district of Kompong Tom Province. 

Mrs. Ke is an energetic woman who never wastes time. She works hard to earn money in the hope that she will be able to help all of her children to attain the highest levels of education. 

Her husband is a blacksmith, and as the family has no transportation, he is obliged to hire a taxi every day to take him to and from work. In order to save money on commuting costs, Mrs. Ke is applying for a Kiva loan in order to buy a used motorcycle, which will be used by her husband to ride to and from his workplace.

loans.use: to buy a used motorcycle, which will be used by her husband to commute to and from his workplace

loans.name: Cholpon's Group

texts.en:
Cholpon is the leader of this group. She is 46 and, unfortunately, she is a widow. She is raising two daughters and a son; her son attends university in Bishkek and her daughters are at school. Cholpon is engaged in agriculture, cultivating agricultural products and breeding livestock animals. She is the Executive Director of the countryside alliance. Her agricultural activities have made it possible for her to improve the family's living conditions and pay for her children’s education. With money received from this loan, Cholpon plans to purchase three sheep in order to increase the number of livestock. In the near future, she wants to start house repairing.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Erdeneselenge

texts.en:
Mrs. Erdeneselenge, 39 years old, lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She currently takes care of her son, who is 3 years old. Mrs. Erdeneselenge married her husband only three years ago and they live in a rented ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband, Mendbayar, has been operating a taxi business for many years. Now he has been registered to a taxi call center which operates in the north suburban side of the city. This area is very busy, especially in the summer, because in warm seasons people tend to move to houses in that area whereas in winter they move back to the city center. This area always lacks bus services.

Erdeneselenge is planning to buy a plot of land upon which to build a family house later on. She has started negotiations and she needs to pay the money for the land. She and her husband are going to use their savings to pay for the land, but still need some additional money. Erdeneselenge is requesting a loan to be used as the remaining payment for the land plot. She has already paid the advance payment.

loans.use: to help pay for a plot of land.

loans.name: Maurene

texts.en:
Maurene is a single mother of five school-going children. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

For the past 6 years, Maurene has operated a business selling clothes and cloth materials, selling at wholesale, retail and door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. Maurene faces major challenges of seasonality and high transportation costs in her business. She dreams of establishing a boutique shop in the future. 

Maurene plans to use this KES 30,000 loan to purchase iron sheets and timber to build a stall for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase iron sheets and timber to build her clothes selling stall.

loans.name: Nanita

texts.en:
Nanita is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Nanita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Nanita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Nanita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nanita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and beverages. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Nanita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and beverages.

loans.name: Augustine

texts.en: Augustine is a 52-year-old hardworking man living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has seven children, and the responsibility to look after the family rests solely on him. He longs to educate his children and build a permanent house. He has been trading in goats for twenty years and business is good despite the challenge of limited funds. His desire is to own a ranch. Augustine needs this loan to buy goats to resell.

loans.use: to purchase goats to resell.

loans.name: Siti

texts.en:
Siti, 46 years old, is married to Zakarias, 50 years old, who works in a private company. They are blessed with 4 children: Murny, 27 years old and married; Sitti, 25 years old and married; Muhammad, 22 years old and graduated from senior high school; Afliana, 8 years old and in 2nd grade. 

Siti has been running her business as a seamstress for years. She learned the skill from her mother when she was young and has continued running the business to generate daily income. Siti's main business challenge is her competitors, as she lives in the middle of town. This situation never makes Siti gives up. She tries her best to keep her sewing of high quality in order to maintain her customers and to attract more customers. Currently her business is running well but she wants to improve it by adding a new sewing machine. Therefore, she is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to IDR 5,000,000. She hopes that the loan will help her improve her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan is a divorced man (his marriage ended 4 years ago) with one child. Chan currently lives with his elderly parents in the Baray district.

Chan is a rice cultivator, who is also engaged in the transportation business. He uses his own horse cart to pick up his neighbors and other villagers who want to buy things at the local market or anywhere else in town. Chan’s horse is getting old, though, and the horse cannot support him to run his transportation service. Therefore, Mr. Chan is seeking some funding from Kiva to buy a new horse.

loans.use: To purchase a new horse.

loans.name: Manilyn

texts.en:
Manilyn is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 20 years old, married and has 1 infant. Manilyn owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling seafood products, such as milk fish and sardines, in the local community. Manilyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Manilyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Manilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish such as mackerel and sardines. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Manilyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish such as mackerel and sardines.

loans.name: Ihtiram

texts.en:
Ihtiram is 35 years old and married to Saad, a 49-year-old nurse. They have six children together. To be able to raise their children and support her husband, Ihtiram decided to use their land to build a barn to raise sheep. A year ago, Ihtiram built a sheep barn where she started with a few sheep. She sold the sheep products such as yogurt and wool and she was able to create a good and healthy environment for them to breed. 

Now, because of the large number of sheep she has, she applied for a loan to expand the barn space, to keep the healthy environment and to increase her productivity.  
 
Since Ihtiram is a conservative person, her husband agreed to appear in the picture.

loans.use: To expand the barn space for her sheep

loans.name: Shama's Group

texts.en:
Shama is 28 years old and married with two children. Both of them are very young and not of school going age yet. Shama is involved in a veterinary medicine business. Her clientele is her community because most people are involved in the livestock business. To keep their cattle healthy, they come to her to buy medicines. She is also a very good housewife and manages her household responsibilities very well. Her husband works in a factory for a low income.  Shama’s father and brother also live with her. Both of them also work and contribute to the family financially, which helps Shama and her husband with the household expenses. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her own business. With the loan, she will buy veterinary medicines for the further improvement of her business. She has been operating this business for the past nine years. She is hopeful that a loan will be productive for her.

loans.use: To buy veterinary medicines to sell

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent and school fees. She has operated a retail shop for the past five years. Her customers are neighbours and passersby. She sells household goods like wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt. Edwina faces a major challenge of price fluctuation leading to low demand for her products. She dreams of owning a wholesale shop in the future. 

With this loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cereals for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 10 bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cereals for sale.

loans.name: Melrose

texts.en: Melrose owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in her community. She is 39 years old, married and has six school-aged children. They are from the village of Kulasihan, Lantapan, Bukidnon. Melrose has been in her business for over six years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2011, Melrose joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Melrose is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional snack foods and canned goods. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional snack foods and canned goods.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 35 years old and married to Grace who is a housewife. They are blessed with four children aged 14, 12, 8 and 2 years old.  He owns a posho mill in the Chemase Trading Centre in Kapsabet town.  He has been in the business for a period of six years, earning a monthly income of KES 10,000.

Moses has borrowed a loan of KES 20,000 from KADET LTD. This is his first loan. He wants to use the loan to purchase dry maize for his posho mill. The anticipated profits will be used to educate his school going children and increase the stock for the business.

He hopes to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To purchase bags of dry maize for his posho mill

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To hire a tractor and buy seedlings

loans.name: Nuriance
loans.use: to purchase eight vegetable plots, seeds, insecticides and fertilizer

loans.name: Camlita

texts.en:
Camlita is married to a businessman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her husband contributes to the family's basic needs with his earnings. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past seven years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality, especially during rainy season when it becomes difficult to operate. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase cement, iron sheets and timber to build a permanent food stall. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cement, iron sheets and timber to build a permanent food stall.

loans.name: Dimitri

texts.en:
Dimitri lives in the village of Sartichala, West Georgia. He is 29 years old, unmarried and lives with his mother and sister. 

Dimitri works as a provider in a village store. He gets a salary for his job. Dimitri’s family also owns three milk cows. The milk is used for cheese production. The cheese is sold in the store where Dimitri works. Dimitri’s sister works as a salesperson in a supermarket in the same village. The total monthly income of the family is 650 Laris. 

Last year, Dimitri received a loan from Credo, part of which was used for starting renovation of his house. The other part was used for expansion of his dairy farm. Now Dimitri received a second loan from Credo. He plans to use it for finalizing the renovation of the house. His family is happy, because finally they will have a renovated house and better living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for materials and services for house renovation

loans.name: Ecinderella

texts.en:
Ecinderella is from the village of Cawayan, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Ecinderella is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Ecinderella owns & operates a business buying and selling vegetable like cauliflower & broccoli in the local community. Ecinderella has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ecinderella joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ecinderella is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional vegetables like cauliflower & broccoli. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ecinderella from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables like cauliflower & broccoli

loans.name: Jallyben

texts.en:
Jallyben is from the village of Cawayan, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 28 years old. Jallyben is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jallyben owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Jallyben has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jallyben joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jallyben has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Jallyben is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jallyben from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods & junk foods

loans.name: Anjeline

texts.en:
Anjeline is a married woman with two children who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Anjeline dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Mike

texts.en:
Mike is 26 years old and married to Jane who is a business lady. They have one child aged three years old.  He is a farmer in Kipsigak and supplies his farm produce to the nearby trading market as well as the people from his locality.  He has been in the business for a period of five years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000.

He is applying for his third loan from KADET LTD, after paying his previous loan well and in good time. He wishes to use the loan to purchase fertilizers for his tilled land that is ready for planting.

He hopes to start a retail shop in Kipsigak Trading Centre.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a hardworking married man with seven children living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He takes care of the family with the help of his wife who is also a farmer. Their dream is to educate their children since they did not have a chance to attain an education. For four years, he has been into farming.  He grows maize and fruit and he has been able to reap very high yields. In a season, he would harvest two bags of maize but he can now harvest seven bags of maize per season. He has the challenge of price fluctuation of agricultural products and his dream is to become a mechanized farmer. Thomas needs the loan to prepare his land for growing maize.

loans.use: To prepare his land for growing maize

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed is very supportive and helpful in nature. She is always ready to help her family in a time of need. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her son’s business selling medicines. He operates his shop in the market and offers good quality medicines to his clients. He will use the loan to buy medicines in bulk to be able to fulfill the demands of his customers and to increase his profits. He has been doing this business for the past four years and Khursheed is confident that a loan will help him make his business more profitable. 

Khursheed is 55 years of age. She stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She is still very active and performs her duties very well.  

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Khursheed.

loans.use: To buy medicines to sell

loans.name: Abdufato

texts.en:
Abdufato is married and has two children. Abdufato is a cheerful and nimble man. He works very hard. Abdufato has the great responsibility of caring for his family, as he is the only breadwinner. His wife is a housewife. For more than 12 years, he has been running his family’s bakery business. His two brothers help him in the business. Abdufato would like to get a loan of 6,000 Somoni to purchase flour in order to expand his business. He is requesting a loan for the fifth time and has a good credit history. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy flour

loans.name: Ruby Pearl

texts.en:
Ruby Pearl is 47 years old and married with two young children. The oldest child is 8 years old.

Ruby Pearl is into the hog-raising business. She is currently renting a space for her piggery. She hopes to have her own piggery so that she can save rent expenses.

Ruby Pearl's loan will be used to purchase feed, vitamins and other supplies. She hopes to improve her business and income. She also hopes to have enough money for the coming enrollment.

loans.use: to purchase feed, vitamins and other supplies

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She sells household goods like sugar, wheat flour, maize flour, and detergents. Her major challenge in the business is stiff competition from other retail shop operators. She dreams of developing and expanding her business in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of detergents, cereals and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of detergents, cereals and cooking oil.

loans.name: Fely

texts.en: At the age of 41, Fely is determined to work hard to supplement their daily expenditures. She is married to a farmer and they are blessed with three children. She decided to take a loan from Kiva lenders and ASKI MFI of PHP 25,000 to purchase additional farm inputs. She earned PHP 18,000 at the last cropping and she has owned and managed her farm for almost two years. Her profits will be used for her family's daily needs. She hopes that Kiva and ASKI MFI will continue to give her financial assistance to gain more income.

loans.use: To purchase additional farm inputs

loans.name: Rahim

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 32 years old, married and has three children.

Rahim has had a shop for selling furniture and household items since 2004. He has good experience in this field and a good reputation. He is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2,500 to renovate his shop and to increase its purchase. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To renovate his shop and buy more products to sell.

loans.name: Abuneri

texts.en:
Abuneri is a 30-year-old married man living in his own semi-permanent house in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He takes care of five of his children and his desire is to educate them to attain a degree as a minimum qualification. 

For three years, he has been operating a pub, and the business has grown despite his challenges with finances. His dream is to have a beer depot. Abuneri needs the credit to buy beer for selling.

loans.use: to buy beer for selling.

loans.name: Hanaa

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 34 years old, married and has five children.

Hanaa has been a tailor since 2007. She makes and repairs women, men and children’s clothing. She has good experience, a good reputation and she is well known in her area.

She is requesting $2,500 to buy a sewing machine and a generator. She is aiming to gain more profit so she can improve her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and a generator.

loans.name: Emzar

texts.en:
Emzar is a 41-year-old farmer from the village of Mukhrovani, Gardabani District. He is married and lives with his wife Madonna and 13-year-old son. Emzar’s son goes to the local school. 

Emzar works in a local petrol station, as an operator. Madonna works as a teacher in the local school. Besides their regular jobs, Emzar and Madonna run a small dairy farm with three milk cows and seven calves. They produce traditional Georgian cheese and sell it in Tbilisi, the capital city of the country. The total average monthly income of the family is approximately 500 Laris. 

With the requested credit, Emzar and Madonna will purchase an additional cow. It will result in increased cheese production. Part of the profit of the farm will be reinvested – more milk cows will be purchased.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Leticia Limos Group

texts.en: Leticia is the leader of the 12 members who are taking a group loan. Leticia is married and 56 years old. She has a retailing business where she sells various vegetables in the community. She has operated this business for almost three years. Leticia is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase vegetable seeds and fertilizers. She will also use the loan to buy vegetables in the market to sell in the villages. She usually earns about PHP 3,000 each month in this business. She hopes that her business will improve while taking the loan.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and various vegetable seeds

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy is a 44-year-old, married woman with 4 children.

Amy works hard to provide for her family. Specifically, for 15 years, she has operated a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She generates additional income as a retailer of rice.

She is now requesting a loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP ($325) through NWTF to purchase more items to sell, such as sugar and other groceries. Notably, Amy has borrowed and successfully repaid 5 prior loans from NWTF. Amy aspires to expand her business to improve her family's standard of living in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional items.

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 36 years old, married and has four children. He lives with eight family members, one of whom works. 

Akram has had a food market since 2008. He gained experience from his father when he was working with him in the same field and has a good reputation. He is well known in his area.

He is requesting $2,400 to buy a generator and an extra refrigerator for his market. He is aiming to develop his work and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a generator and an extra refrigerator for his market.

loans.name: Diyaa

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 45 years old, married and has three children.

In 2009, Diyaa opened a food market. He has four years experience in this field, a good reputation and is well known in his area.

He is requesting $3,000 to renovate his shop and to make a sliding door for it. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To renovate his shop and to make a sliding door for it.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past 4 years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She sells household goods such as cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour and rice. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Irene dreams of establishing another business in the future.

With the Kshs 80,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cereals, detergent and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase cereals, detergent and cooking oil.

loans.name: Wyclife

texts.en:
Wyclife is 23 years old and he owns a store in the Kimaam trading centre where he sells animal feed.  He has been in the business for a period of three years getting a monthly income of KES. 15,600.

He has been given a loan of KES. 30,000 from KADET LTD as his first loan, and he will use the loan to purchase animal feed:  10 bags of chicken feed and 10 bags of dairy feed to sell.  The anticipated profits will be used to expand his business.

He hopes and dreams of owning a lorry to assist him in transportation.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed, chicken feed and dairy feeds

loans.name: Nazeeran's Group

texts.en:
Nazeeran is 35 years old and married with five children. All of them are very young and have not started their studies yet. She is a housewife and does her household responsibilities by staying at home. 

Her husband is a loader by profession and operates a loading/unloading business. He provides his services from his donkey cart and delivers the goods to the designated places. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband to buy a new cart because his current cart has become rough and needs to be replaced. He is the only earning person in the family and it is necessary that his business become established. He has been operating this business for the past four years and Nazeeran is hopeful that after the loan, it will start bringing him better profits.

loans.use: To buy a new cart for loading business

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima is a 54-year-old mother of one daughter, Fatima is a housewife and her husband is an employee with a decent salary. Fatima wants to replace the old home furniture that she has been using for 30 years with new furniture. Fatima took out a $1,000 loan from FATEN for this purpose.

Fatima is photographed in FATEN's branch office in Jabalia Refugee camp.

loans.use: to replace her 30-year-old home furniture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy potatoes, onions and a cart for transportation

loans.name: Emalia

texts.en: Emalia currently sells beer.  She is 30 years old and married, with 2 children, one of whom attends school. Emalia took out a loan to stock more beer to sell. She hopes to open a big shop in the future with extra profits from her business.

loans.use: To stock more beer to sell.

loans.name: Musanga

texts.en:
Musanga has practised farming in Naivasha town for the past five years. He is 37 years old, married to Jane and they have three children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers.  This will be his third loan.  He repaid all his previous loans well and on time. He plans to use the new loan to buy more sheep which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

In future, Musanga hopes to become a leading livestock farmer in Naivasha town, and give his children a better education.

loans.use: To buy more sheep which he will rear and sell later

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en: Abraham is 55 years old and married with four school-aged children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns approximately PHP 10,000 each month. Abraham is asking for a loan of PHP 45,000 to buy hog feed and other supplies. He has been doing this business for 23 years. Abraham wishes to maintain his business to provide his children needs in school and the basic necessities of his family.

loans.use: to buy hog feed and other supplies

loans.name: Ivane

texts.en:
Ivane is a 41-year-old worker from the village of Badiauri, East Georgia. He is unmarried and lives with his younger brother and mother. 

Ivane is a worker for the Georgian Railway Company. Along with his regular job, Ivane and his brother are leading the farming activities of the family. In particular, they have 3 milk cows and 36 sheep. They sell traditional Georgian cheese and lambs on the local market. 

With the requested loan, Ivane plans to cultivate the family-owned plot and plant watermelon. He plans to sell the harvested watermelons locally to the retailers of fruits and vegetables. Part of the gained profit will be used for covering family everyday expenses and the other part will be reinvested in the dairy farm.

loans.use: to pay for cultivation of the land and watermelon seeds

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer, 45 years old and single, resides at Bacnor East, Burgos, Isabela. With her desire to help her parents with their daily needs, she engages in a hog raising business. She fattens and sells the hogs. She has been doing this business for almost five years.

At present, Jenifer is borrowing PHP 25,000 to purchase livestock feed and other needed supplies for her livelihood. She hopes that with the loan, her profit will increase. With hard work, Jenifer believes that nothing is impossible.

loans.use: to buy feed for pigs

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a married woman with 3 children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bills and school fees. 

For the past 6 years, she has been selling clothes especially for men.  She sells wholesale, retail, at the market and from door to door. Her major challenge is seasonality.  During the December holidays she has many customers purchasing clothes, compared to other months where sales are very low.  Rebecca dreams of establishing a well-stocked boutique in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase bundles of sodas, mineral water and a freezer. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of sodas, mineral water and a freezer.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter, aged 33, is married to Faith.  The couple is blessed with three children. He practices poultry keeping and has been  in the business for one year.  The business earns him a monthly income of KES 35,000.

This is his third loan cycle from KADET LTD.  Peter has a good credit history with KADET LTD.  He intends to use the loan funds to buy broiler chicks worth KES 30,000 and chicken feed worth 20,000.

Peter will use the anticipated profits to support his family.  He hopes to establish his business and take it to a higher level.

loans.use: To buy chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock more beans to sell.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius, aged 33, is married with three children aged between twelve and five years.

He sells curios in Westlands, Nairobi, and has been doing this business for the last three years, which earns him a monthly income of 18,000 KES.

This is his first loan from KADET Ltd.  Julius will use the loan funds to buy more curios for his business. He will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for his children and he hopes to open a business for his wife in the future.

loans.use: to buy more curio stock

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony is 34 years old and married with three children.  He runs a curio shop to earn a living.  He has been in the business for five years. Through Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to keep business records.  This has helped him to manage his business well.

He hopes to expand his business and employ more people.  He has requested 40,000 KES to buy carvings, paints and African design fabric.

loans.use: to buy carvings, paints and African design fabric

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Salma is a housewife who spends most of her time staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. She has given birth to six children.  None of them is able to attend school due to financial constraints. Her husband operates a donkey cart. He offers loading and unloading services to his customers. He is very good at his work and delivers the goods on time to the designated places. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who wants to buy a new donkey cart because his current cart has become rough and rotten. The new cart will help him put more loads on it and provide better services to his customers. He is the only breadwinner of the family. Salma is hopeful that the loan will be helpful for her husband and will make his work easy and increase his profits. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Salma.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock more beans and onions to sell.

loans.name: Sameeha

texts.en: Sameeha is 54 years old and a hard working mom. She started a small retail business selling blankets at her home. Doing that for three years has given her the urge to expand her business and include clothes to the products she sells. In order for her to expand her business by opening her own store, she has applied for this loan to buy her products from the supplier in larger quantities to get them at a lower price so she can make more profit from selling the products.

loans.use: To buy more products (blankets and clothes) in larger quantities

loans.name: Otgonmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Otgonmaa is 27 years old and lives with her husband and 2 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband works for the public service. They live in their own family house which they built two years ago.

Since 2008, Otgonmaa has been running a window guard manufacturing business. She uses her backyard as a workshop. Her main customers are house owners. She buys metal and iron materials from a wholesale place at the market and makes different metal guards for windows with different designs. Her products helps house owners to protect their homes from intruders.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy different metal and iron materials to make metal guards for house windows.

loans.use: to buy different metal materials to make metal guards for house windows.

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima is married and the mother of a 21-year-old son who works on a poultry farm. Fatima could not educate him. That’s why he is unable to find a better job. Fatima is a very supportive lady in nature. She operates a grocery store in her home and also sells traditional Punjabi dishes called Samosy & Pakorey. The income she earns helps her pay the utility bills. Fatima has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her grocery store business. With the loan, she will buy groceries to put in store to sell. She has been operating her business for the past four years and hopes that a loan will help her to increase her profits.

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Fatima.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Yesu Asobola Development Group

texts.en:
35-year-old Rose  (pictured with a raised hand) has been retailing for 6 years in Natete, an upscale suburb of Kampala city. 

The happily married mother of 2 says she began this business with the little savings she had from her charcoal sales business. She says that hard work has enabled her make the strides she has made over the course of the last few years. Rose also runs a small clinic. Her weekly profits are to the tune of 50,000 shillings. 

With this loan she says she is going to purchase more retail commodities like sugar, soap and rice to sell at her shop.

Aidah is not seen clearly in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase more retail commodities such as sugar and soap to resell
